repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Poverty Reduction and Local
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Poverty Reduction and
            Local Development Project for Nicaragua were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: bottom-up and demand-driven initiatives can
            improve the quality and relevance of social and economic
            investments. Community Driven Development Projects (CDD)
            must be integrated with local government programs rather
            than by-pass them in order to ensure long-term
            sustainability of the small-scale social and economic
            investments carried out at the community level, provide
            enabling conditions for the scaling up and prevent erosion
            of local capacity. The choice of targeting approach is
            relevant for equity, transparency, program ownership and
            effectiveness. The Nicaraguan State needs to significantly
            strengthen its coordinating efforts among line Ministries
            and agencies to increase effectiveness and efficiencies in a
            context of limited financial, physical and technical
            resources. Impact evaluation included at the onset of
            project implementation and monitoring are needed as a means
            to correct course if it becomes necessary. They also provide
            appropriate information to test alternative mechanisms,
            prior to scaling-up. This project paid close attention to
            establishing a functional Management Information System
            (MIS) and a series of evaluations. Ensuring implementation
            readiness conditions prior to negotiations leads to a more
            effective and timely physical and financial execution cycle.

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Poverty Reduction and Local
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction and Local
            Development Project, will assist the Government of Nicaragua
            by partially implementing the poverty reduction strategy,
            and by continuing to improve access to small-scale social,
            and economic infrastructure to the poor. The components
            include: 1) subproject financing, to enable a continued
            support from the Emergency Social Investment Fund (FISE), in
            the replacement, expansion, and improvement of basic social
            services. Training in community organization, operations,
            and maintenance will be provided. The component aims at
            improving the quality, and comprehensiveness of investments;
            ensuring community participation; coordinating with service
            providers to ensure adequate supply-side interventions; and,
            addressing the specific needs of indigenous populations; 2)
            financing of participatory municipal planning, which
            includes technical assistance (TA), and training provision
            for communities, and municipalities alike, so as to be able
            to conduct future planning by themselves. Decentralization
            of subproject management will continue, through TA from
            FISE, while capacity building will be provided not only to
            communities, and municipalities, but to private
            stakeholders; 3) supporting the development of safety nets
            within a strengthened social protection strategy, and
            improved management of public investments in social areas,
            including monitoring and evaluation of safety net programs.
            An innovation fund will be established within FISE to pilot
            safety net measures for poverty reduction; and, 4) project
            management covering institutional strengthening, supply of
            equipment, and external auditing.
